name: Mixed recyclables, recovered for material recycling facility (MRF)
description:
This attributional unit process LCI represents the breakdown in percentages of sources of postconsumer material collected for material recycling facilities (MRFs). The process only represents the source mix percentages per 1 kg; no incoming transport is included in this process. Transport to the MRF and energy requirements for sorting are included in the next step in this linked model. The LCI study was conducted by Franklin Associates, Ltd. and sponsored jointly by NAPCOR, the American Chemistry Council (ACC), the Association of Postconsumer Plastic Recyclers (APR), and the PET Resin Association (PETRA). Using life cycle inventory (LCI) methodology, the study determines and quantifies the energy requirements, solid wastes, and atmospheric and waterborne emissions for the processes required to collect postconsumer PET and HDPE packaging, sort and separate the material, and reprocess it into clean recycled resin.

Important note: although most of the data in the US LCI database has undergone some sort of review, the database as a whole has not yet undergone a formal validation process. Please email comments to lci@nrel.gov.

category.name: 5629: Remediation and Other Waste Management Services
categoryPath: 56: Administrative and Support and Waste Management and Remediation Services

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data compiled 2010 from most recent sources
processDocumentation.dataCollectionDescription: Data compiled 2010 from most recent sources
processDocumentation.completenessDescription:
TREATMENT OF MISSING ENVIRONMENTAL DATA
Elementary flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance.

TREATMENT OF MISSING TECHNOSPHERE DATA
Intermediate flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance. Capital equipment is not included in this unit process.

MASS BALANCE
Based on 1 kg recyclables by % from source type.
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription:
The percent of PET, HDPE and PP recovery through the various collection programs was determined from an analysis of the following data sources:

National PET, HDPE and PP Recovery for 2015: U.S. EPA. Advancing SustainableMaterials Management: Facts and Figures 2015. https://www.epa.gov/facts-and-figures-about-materials-waste-and-
recycling/advancing-sustainable-materials-management

Curbside/Drop-off/Deposit Mix:
 Governmental Advisory Associates, Inc. 2016-2017 Materials Recycling and Processing in the United States Database. 2016.
 California Department of Resources Recycling and Recovery. November 7, 2016. Biannual Report of Beverage Container Sales, Returns, Redemption, and Recycling Rates. Accessed 16 February 2017. http://www.calrecycle.ca.gov
 California Department of Conservation Division of Recycling. June 2009. Market Analysis for Recycled Beverage Container Materials: 2009 Update. Accessed 16 February 2017
http://www.calrecycle.ca.gov/Publications/Documents/BevContainer/2011024.pdf

Commercial Recovery:
 PET and HDPE containers calculated as total recovery minus residential recovery and deposit recovery
 PP commercial recovery assumed to be negligible.
processDocumentation.reviewDetails: The LCI study was conducted by Franklin Associates, Ltd. and sponsored jointly by NAPCOR, the American Chemistry Council (ACC), the Association of Postconsumer Plastic Recyclers (APR), and the PET Resin Association (PETRA). Using life cycle inventory (LCI) methodology, the study determines and quantifies the energy requirements, solid wastes, and atmospheric and waterborne emissions for the processes required to collect postconsumer PET and HDPE packaging, sort and separate the material, and reprocess it into clean recycled resin. The data has had a partial critical review by internal parties.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Assumtions and calculations described in Modeling Constants.
processDocumentation.inventoryMethodDescription: Attributional; data sets for the three recycling unit processes (collection, sorting/separation, reclaimer operations) were linked to cover the full sequence of processing steps required to produce recycled resins  gate-to-gate results; for cradle-to-gate LCI of recycled resin, the practitioner needs to make decision about virgin resin burdens associated with the postconsumer products that are feedstocks to recycling. Recycling occurs in the context of a product made from resin; use and end-of-life management of the material will depend on the product in which it is used
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: See Section 2.2 and Table 2-1 in source report. Curbside includes deposit and non-deposit containers collected through curbside; Deposit includes deposit and non-deposit containers collected through deposit centers; Data collected on HDPE recovery excludes HDPE film packaging
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
Includes the breakdown in percentages of sources of postconsumer material arriving at material recycling facilities (MRFs). The process only represents the source mix and Incoming transport is not included in this unit process. 

DATA COLLECTION
Assumptions and calculations are described in Modeling Constants and the supporting documentation.

UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATION
No uncertainty estimations were included.

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: "Accounting, with system-external interactions" - The intended application is a purely descriptive accounting / documentation of the analysed system including existing interactions with other systems in the LCI model.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: LIFE CYCLE INVENTORY OF 100% POSTCONSUMER HDPE AND PET RECYCLED RESIN FROM POSTCONSUMER CONTAINERS AND PACKAGING PREPARED FOR THE PLASTICS DIVISION OF THE AMERICAN CHEMISTRY COUNCIL, INC. THE ASSOCIATION OF POSTCONSUMER PLASTIC RECYCLERS (APR), THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR PET CONTAINER RESOURCES (NAPCOR), AND THE PET RESIN ASSOCIATION (PETRA) BY FRANKLIN ASSOCIATES, A DIVISION OF ERG PRAIRIE VILLAGE, KANSAS JANUARY 19, 2011.
